content: I was reading Theorem Proving in Lean 4 and am trying to understand the basics of dependent type theory. If I understand this correctly, I can define new inductive types in any universe, but universes aren't something that can be defined, they're a consequence of all types being a term of some type? sort 0, sort 1, sort 2 ... and so on are all the universes?
I suppose that doesn't make sense. The point of a universe, to quantify over types after all...
If I create a term - Foo - with the type Type 2, then it is in the same universe as Type 1. Just like Type 1 is a universe, so is Foo?

Can you make your question a little more precise? You can define inductive type in any universe you want, so for example you can define your new copy of natural numbers as

inductive N : Type 5
| zero : N
| succ : N → N

This type N will behave essentially as the usual ℕ, but you have N : Type 5.
Would you say that N is a universe? It's in the same universe as Type 4 and Type 4 is a universe...
Technically the statement N = Type 4 is (probably) undecidable, but you should treat them as different.
So in the Calculus of Constructions, you dont define universes, they're already there.
I can define a new type in any universe, but I don't define a new universe? I'm not sure if that's a very precise question or not
Yes, the whole countable hierarchy is already there, it's not defined.
Okay. I think that answers my question. Thanks :)
Treq has marked this topic as resolved.

Riccardo Brasca said:

Technically the statement N = Type 4 is (probably) undecidable, but you should treat them as different.

Shouldn't you be able to prove they are distinct by cardinality reasons?
Ah, that's possible, I have no idea about the cardinality of Type u. Anyway that's the only possible way of proving it.

which deduces that #cardinal.{u} ≤ #Type u < #cardinal.{u+1} is about all we can prove; this is sufficient in this case since it means that every type is at least as large as the cardinal numbers, which are very large (containing all the aleph numbers) and therefore are uncountable, unlike N
